news_summary: Today’s space news highlights groundbreaking achievements in capturing the formation of a solar system, advancing scalable satellite technology for faster sensor deployment, developing innovative super-cold fuel storage methods, and capturing detailed images of a galaxy cluster.
news_summary_fr: L'actualité spatiale d'aujourd'hui met en lumière des réalisations révolutionnaires qui ont permis de saisir la formation d'un système solaire, de faire progresser la technologie des satellites évolutifs pour un déploiement plus rapide des capteurs, de mettre au point des méthodes innovantes de stockage des carburants à très basse température et de capturer des images détaillées d'un amas de galaxies.
news_summary_es: Las noticias espaciales de hoy destacan logros revolucionarios en la captación de la formación de un sistema solar, el avance de la tecnología de satélites escalables para un despliegue más rápido de sensores, el desarrollo de métodos innovadores de almacenamiento de combustible superfrío y la captación de imágenes detalladas de un cúmulo de galaxias.

articles.title: Daily briefing: The birth of a solar system caught ‘on camera’ for the first time
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 17 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02299-yResearchers have spotted a baby star at the beginning of its planet forming era. Plus, eight babies conceived via ‘three-person in vitro fertilization’ are living healthy lives and the best popular science and scholarly books to read now.
articles.content:
Researchers have spotted a baby star at the beginning of its planet forming era. Plus, eight babies conceived via ‘three-person in vitro fertilization’ are living healthy lives and the best popular science and scholarly books to read now.

Hello Nature readers, would you like to get this Briefing in your inbox free every day? Sign up here.

HOPS-315, as imaged by the Atacama Large Millimeter-submillimeter Array in Chile (orange is carbon monoxide blowing away from the central star, blue is silicon monoxide).Credit: ALMA(ESO/NAOJ/NRAO)/M. McClure et al.

Astronomers have spotted a solar system beyond our own in its very earliest stages of formation. Using both ground- and space-based telescopes, the team zeroed in on the young star, named HOPS-315, at the start of its planet-forming era. The baby star was at just the right orientation for astronomers to get a glimpse of its surrounding disk of gas and dust, which is usually obscured by jets of gas pumped out by newborn stars. Researchers have long sought such a system to help them understand the humble beginnings of our own.

Nature | 4 min read

Reference: Nature paper

Eight children conceived through a controversial reproductive technique called mitochondrial donation are living healthy lives. The procedure, dubbed ‘three-person in vitro fertilization’, involves transferring the nucleus of a fertilized egg that has faulty mitochondria into a donor egg with healthy ones. As a result, the children carry nuclear DNA from a biological mother and father, alongside mitochondrial DNA from a separate egg donor. The technique aims to prevent babies inheriting harmful mutations from their mother’s mitochondrial DNA, which can cause debilitating diseases that affect power-hungry tissues such as the heart and muscles.

Nature | 5 min read

Reference: New England Journal of Medicine paper 1 & paper 2

Drosophila research hasn’t fallen victim to the ‘reproducibility crisis’, a new study suggests. Of more than 1,000 claims about the fruit flies’ immunity in scientific papers published over some 50 years, at least 61% are verifiable through replication. Only 7% had been challenged and proved not to be reproducible. “There is a narrative of a ‘reproducibility crisis’ in science, which sounds dramatic,” says study co-author and Drosophila researcher Mark Hanson, but adds that the scientists themselves are rarely that worried. In the field of fly genetics, “we constantly build on each other’s work”, he says.

Nature | 5 min read

Reference: bioRxiv preprint 1 & preprint 2

Kimi K2, launched by Moonshot AI, is the second powerful artificial intelligence (AI) model to emerge from China, after DeepSeek shocked the world with its launch of R1 in January. Kimi K2 appears to excel at coding, scoring high in tests of code-related tasks. A big advantage of both models is that they are open-weight, meaning they can be downloaded and built upon by researchers for free. Kimi K2 is “the new best open model in the world”, wrote machine-learning researcher Nathan Lambert in a social post.

Nature | 5 min read

Features & opinion

Illustration: Bratislav Milenkovic

Nature contributors’ pick of the best popular science and scholarly books to read now (even if it’s winter — I see you, Southern Hemisphere) include a lyrical exploration of the science of sounds and a deep dive into the reproducibility crisis in biomedical science.

Nature | 10 min read

Biomedical researcher João Conde has seen first-hand what US cuts to science funding means: his cancer-research work in Portugal, done in collaboration with colleagues in the United Kingdom and United States, is now under threat. “The dangers of depending so much on one nation are becoming clear,” he says. Funding and decision-making responsibilities should be spread among more countries, he argues, and all this must be underpinned by shared databases and research-management platforms.

Nature | 5 min read

We have a host of information about ourselves at our fingertips, but often choose to avoid or ignore it. The reasons for this information avoidance fall into three broad categories, explains psychologist Jeremy Foust: protecting a belief, avoiding an undesired action and reducing negative emotions. What’s less clear cut is the extent to which it impacts us. Choosing not to ‘doomscroll’ negative news can benefit our mental health in the short term, but to only engage with what we want to hear can lead us down a rabbit hole of increasingly biased views.

Psyche | 9 min read
articles.reasoning: The article highlights several positive scientific breakthroughs including the first direct observation of a solar system in its earliest formation stage, successful births of children via a cutting-edge reproductive technology, and advances in AI and scientific reproducibility. These stories inspire hope about human knowledge, medical progress, and our understanding of the universe.
articles.personality_title: Scientists capture the birth of a solar system for the first time
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists have long dreamed of seeing how solar systems form, but capturing the very beginning has been a challenge because it happens far away and over long times.

**What happened**
Using a powerful telescope in Chile, researchers spotted a baby star named HOPS-315 just as it is starting to form planets around it. This is the first time we've seen this early stage so clearly.

**Impact**
This discovery helps us understand how stars and planets, including our own solar system, begin their journey. It also opens doors to learning more about the conditions that allow planets to form and possibly support life.

**What's next step**
Scientists will continue watching HOPS-315 and similar stars to gather more details about planet formation. This ongoing study could reveal more about how our universe creates new worlds.

**One-sentence takeaway**
For the first time, we have a real glimpse of a solar system being born, shining new light on the origins of planets and stars.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques capturent la naissance d’un système solaire pour la première fois
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les scientifiques rêvent depuis longtemps de voir comment les systèmes solaires se forment, mais observer le tout début a été un défi car cela se passe très loin et sur de longues périodes.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Grâce à un puissant télescope au Chili, des chercheurs ont repéré une étoile bébé nommée HOPS-315 au moment où elle commence à former des planètes autour d’elle. C’est la première fois que nous voyons cette étape si précocement et clairement.

**Impact**
Cette découverte nous aide à comprendre comment les étoiles et les planètes, y compris notre système solaire, commencent leur voyage. Cela ouvre aussi la voie à mieux connaître les conditions permettant la formation des planètes et peut-être la vie.

**Prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques vont continuer à observer HOPS-315 et des étoiles similaires pour recueillir plus de détails sur la formation planétaire. Cette étude en cours pourrait révéler comment notre univers crée de nouveaux mondes.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
Pour la première fois, nous avons un véritable aperçu de la naissance d’un système solaire, éclairant l’origine des planètes et des étoiles.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos capturan por primera vez el nacimiento de un sistema solar
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los científicos han soñado durante mucho tiempo con ver cómo se forman los sistemas solares, pero capturar el inicio ha sido un desafío porque ocurre muy lejos y en largos periodos.

**Qué pasó**
Usando un telescopio poderoso en Chile, los investigadores detectaron una estrella bebé llamada HOPS-315 justo cuando empieza a formar planetas a su alrededor. Esta es la primera vez que vemos esta etapa tan temprano y claramente.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento nos ayuda a entender cómo las estrellas y planetas, incluido nuestro sistema solar, comienzan su camino. También abre puertas para aprender más sobre las condiciones que permiten la formación de planetas y posiblemente la vida.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos continuarán observando HOPS-315 y estrellas similares para obtener más detalles sobre la formación de planetas. Este estudio en curso podría revelar cómo nuestro universo crea nuevos mundos.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Por primera vez, tenemos una vista real del nacimiento de un sistema solar, iluminando el origen de planetas y estrellas.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a glowing newborn star at the center of a swirling disk of fine gas and dust, with delicate streams of orange and blue representing flowing cosmic gases gently spiraling outward, set against a soft dark space background with subtle hints of distant, faint stars.

articles.title: NASA Tests Scalable Satellite Tech to Launch Sensors Quicker
articles.summary: NASA’s Athena Economical Payload Integration Cost mission, or Athena EPIC, is a test launch for an innovative, scalable space vehicle design to support future missions. The small satellite platform is engineered to share resources among the payloads onboard by managing routine functions so the individual payloads don’t have to. This technology results in lower costs […]
articles.content:
NASA’s Athena Economical Payload Integration Cost mission, or Athena EPIC, is a test launch for an innovative, scalable space vehicle design to support future missions. The small satellite platform is engineered to share resources among the payloads onboard by managing routine functions so the individual payloads don’t have to.

This technology results in lower costs to taxpayers and a quicker path to launch.

Fully integrated, the Athena EPIC satellite undergoes performance testing in a NovaWurks cleanroom to prepare the sensor for launch. The optical module payload element may be seen near the top of the instrument with the single small telescope. NovaWurks

“Increasing the speed of discovery is foundational to NASA. Our ability to leverage access to innovative space technologies across federal agencies through industry partners is the future,” said Clayton Turner, Associate Administrator for Space Technology Mission Directorate at NASA headquarters in Washington. “Athena EPIC is a valuable demonstration of the government at its best — serving humankind to advance knowledge with existing hardware configured to operate with new technologies.”

NOAA (National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration) and the U.S. Space Force are government partners for this demo mission. Athena EPIC’s industry partner, NovaWurks, provided the space vehicle, which utilizes a small satellite platform assembled with a Hyper-Integrated Satlet, or HISat.

Engineers at NovaWurks in Long Beach prepare to mount the optical payload subassembly (center, silver) consisting of the payload optical module and single telescope mounted between gimbals on each of two HISats on either side of the module which will allow scanning across the Earth’s surface. NovaWurks

The HISat instruments are similar in nature to a child’s toy interlocking building blocks. They’re engineered to be built into larger structures called SensorCraft. Those SensorCraft can share resources with multiple payloads and conform to different sizes and shapes to accommodate them. This easily configurable, building-block architecture allows a lot of flexibility with payload designs and concepts, ultimately giving payload providers easier, less expensive access to space and increased maneuverability between multiple orbits.

Scientists at NASA’s Langley Research Center in Hampton, Virginia, designed and built the Athena sensor payload, which consists of an optical module, a calibration module, and a newly developed sensor electronics assembly. Athena EPIC’s sensor was built with spare parts from NASA’s CERES (Clouds and the Earth’s Radiant Energy System) mission. Several different generations of CERES satellite and space station instruments have tracked Earth’s radiation budget.

“Instead of Athena carrying its own processor, we’re using the processors on the HISats to control things like our heaters and do some of the control functions that typically would be done by a processor on our payload,” said Kory Priestley, principal investigator for Athena EPIC from NASA Langley. “So, this is merging an instrument and a satellite platform into what we are calling a SensorCraft. It’s a more integrated approach. We don’t need as many capabilities built into our key instrument because it’s being brought to us by the satellite host. We obtain greater redundancy, and it simplifies our payload.”

The fully assembled and tested Athena EPIC satellite which incorporates eight HISats mounted on a mock-up of a SpaceX provided launch pedestal which will hold Athena during launch. NovaWurks

This is the first HISat mission led by NASA. Traditional satellites, like the ones that host the CERES instruments — are large, sometimes the size of a school bus, and carry multiple instruments. They tend to be custom units built with all of their own hardware and software to manage control, propulsion, cameras, carousels, processors, batteries, and more, and sometimes even require two of everything to guard against failures in the system. All of these factors, plus the need for a larger launch vehicle, significantly increase costs.

This transformational approach to getting instruments into space can reduce the cost from billions to millions per mission. “Now we are talking about something much smaller — SensorCraft the size of a mini refrigerator,” said Priestley. “If you do have failures on orbit, you can replace these much more economically. It’s a very different approach moving forward for Earth observation.”

The Athena EPIC satellite is shown here mounted onto a vibration table during pre-launch environmental testing. The optical payload is located at the top in this picture with the two solar arrays, stowed for launch, flanking the lower half sides of the satellite. NovaWurks

Athena EPIC is scheduled to launch July 22 as a rideshare on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket from Vandenberg Space Force Base, California. The primary NASA payload on the launch will be the TRACERS (Tandem Reconnection and Cusp Electrodynamics Reconnaissance Satellites) mission. The TRACERS mission is led by the University of Iowa for NASA’s Heliophysics Division within the Science Mission Directorate. NASA’s Earth Science Division also provided funding for Athena EPIC.

“Langley Research Center has long been a leader in developing remote sensing instruments for in-orbit satellites. As satellites become smaller, a less traditional, more efficient path to launch is needed in order to decrease complexity while simultaneously increasing the value of exploration, science, and technology measurements for the Nation,” added Turner.

For more information on NASA’s Athena EPIC mission:

https://science.nasa.gov/misshttps://science.nasa.gov/mission/athena/ion/athena/
articles.reasoning: The article highlights NASA's innovative and cost-effective satellite technology that promises to accelerate space missions and reduce costs significantly. This advancement supports scientific discovery, government collaboration, and more accessible space exploration, which is positive and hopeful for the future.
articles.personality_title: NASA’s new satellite tech speeds up launches and cuts costs
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
NASA is always working on smarter ways to explore space. Their latest project, called Athena EPIC, aims to create a satellite platform that can carry multiple sensors while sharing resources onboard. This helps reduce complexity and cost.

**What happened**
NASA successfully tested the Athena EPIC satellite, designed to manage routine tasks for its sensors so each one doesn’t have to handle everything alone. This sharing system makes the satellite smaller, cheaper, and faster to launch.

**Impact**
This breakthrough means future space missions can get off the ground more quickly and affordably. Lower costs also mean taxpayers benefit, and scientists can send more experiments into space, speeding up discoveries.

**What's next step**
NASA will continue refining this scalable satellite design and use it for upcoming missions. The goal is to make space exploration easier and more accessible by launching multiple payloads together efficiently.

**One-sentence takeaway**
NASA’s Athena EPIC satellite technology promises faster, cheaper space missions by sharing resources among sensors onboard.
articles.personality_title_fr: La nouvelle technologie satellite de la NASA accélère les lancements et réduit les coûts
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
La NASA cherche constamment des moyens plus intelligents d’explorer l’espace. Leur dernier projet, appelé Athena EPIC, vise à créer une plateforme satellite pouvant accueillir plusieurs capteurs en partageant les ressources à bord. Cela aide à réduire la complexité et les coûts.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
La NASA a testé avec succès le satellite Athena EPIC, conçu pour gérer les tâches courantes de ses capteurs afin que chacun n’ait pas à tout gérer seul. Ce système de partage rend le satellite plus petit, moins cher et plus rapide à lancer.

**Impact**
Cette avancée signifie que les futures missions spatiales pourront décoller plus rapidement et à moindre coût. La baisse des coûts profite aussi aux contribuables, et les scientifiques peuvent envoyer plus d’expériences dans l’espace, accélérant ainsi les découvertes.

**Prochaine étape**
La NASA va continuer à améliorer ce design satellite évolutif et l’utiliser pour les prochaines missions. L’objectif est de faciliter et rendre plus accessible l’exploration spatiale en lançant plusieurs charges utiles ensemble efficacement.

**En une phrase**
La technologie satellite Athena EPIC de la NASA promet des missions spatiales plus rapides et moins coûteuses grâce au partage des ressources entre capteurs à bord.
articles.personality_title_es: La nueva tecnología satelital de la NASA acelera los lanzamientos y reduce costos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
La NASA siempre busca formas más inteligentes de explorar el espacio. Su último proyecto, llamado Athena EPIC, pretende crear una plataforma satelital que pueda llevar múltiples sensores compartiendo recursos a bordo. Esto ayuda a reducir la complejidad y los costos.

**Qué pasó**
La NASA probó con éxito el satélite Athena EPIC, diseñado para gestionar las tareas rutinarias de sus sensores para que cada uno no tenga que hacerlo solo. Este sistema de compartición hace que el satélite sea más pequeño, barato y rápido de lanzar.

**Impacto**
Este avance significa que futuras misiones espaciales pueden despegar más rápido y de forma más económica. La reducción de costos también beneficia a los contribuyentes, y los científicos pueden enviar más experimentos al espacio, acelerando los descubrimientos.

**Próximo paso**
La NASA seguirá mejorando este diseño satelital escalable y lo usará en próximas misiones. El objetivo es facilitar y hacer más accesible la exploración espacial lanzando varias cargas útiles juntas de manera eficiente.

**Resumen en una frase**
La tecnología del satélite Athena EPIC de la NASA promete misiones espaciales más rápidas y económicas gracias al uso compartido de recursos entre los sensores a bordo.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a small, modular satellite composed of interlocking building-block-like units orbiting above a softly glowing Earth, with gentle beams of light symbolizing shared resources connecting the satellite’s telescope and instruments, all rendered in natural, muted tones against a calm space background.

articles.title: Stay Cool: NASA Tests Innovative Technique for Super Cold Fuel Storage
articles.summary: In the vacuum of space, where temperatures can plunge to minus 455 degrees Fahrenheit, it might seem like keeping things cold would be easy. But the reality is more complex for preserving ultra-cold fluid propellants – or fuel – that can easily overheat from onboard systems, solar radiation, and spacecraft exhaust. The solution is a […]
articles.content:
In the vacuum of space, where temperatures can plunge to minus 455 degrees Fahrenheit, it might seem like keeping things cold would be easy. But the reality is more complex for preserving ultra-cold fluid propellants – or fuel – that can easily overheat from onboard systems, solar radiation, and spacecraft exhaust. The solution is a method called cryogenic fluid management, a suite of technologies that stores, transfers, and measures super cold fluids for the surface of the Moon, Mars, and future long-duration spaceflight missions.

Super cold, or cryogenic, fluids like liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen are the most common propellants for space exploration. Despite its chilling environment, space has a “hot” effect on these propellants because of their low boiling points – about minus 424 degrees Fahrenheit for liquid hydrogen and about minus 298 for liquid oxygen – putting them at risk of boiloff.

In a first-of-its-kind demonstration, teams at NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama, are testing an innovative approach to achieve zero boiloff storage of liquid hydrogen using two stages of active cooling which could prevent the loss of valuable propellant.

“Technologies for reducing propellant loss must be implemented for successful long-duration missions to deep space like the Moon and Mars,” said Kathy Henkel, acting manager of NASA’s Cryogenic Fluid Management Portfolio Project, based at NASA Marshall. “Two-stage cooling prevents propellant loss and successfully allows for long-term storage of propellants whether in transit or on the surface of a planetary body.”

The new technique, known as “tube on tank” cooling, integrates two cryocoolers, or cooling devices, to keep propellant cold and thwart multiple heat sources. Helium, chilled to about minus 424 degrees Fahrenheit, circulates through tubes attached to the outer wall of the propellant tank.

NASA’s two-stage cooling testing setup sits in a vacuum chamber in Test Stand 300 at NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama. NASA/Tom Perrin The tank for NASA’s two-stage cooling tests is lowered into a vacuum chamber in Test Stand 300 at NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama. NASA/Kathy Henkel The tank for NASA’s two-stage cooling tests is lowered into a vacuum chamber in Test Stand 300 at NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama. NASA/Kathy Henkel The tank for NASA’s two-stage cooling tests is lowered into a vacuum chamber in Test Stand 300 at NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama. NASA/Kathy Henkel

Teams installed the propellant tank in a test stand at NASA Marshall in early June, and the 90-day test campaign is scheduled to conclude in September. The tank is wrapped in a multi-layer insulation blanket that includes a thin aluminum heat shield fitted between layers. A second set of tubes, carrying helium at about minus 298 Fahrenheit, is integrated into the shield. This intermediate cooling layer intercepts and rejects incoming heat before it reaches the tank, easing the heat load on the tube-on-tank system.

To prevent dangerous pressure buildup in the propellant tank in current spaceflight systems, boiloff vapors must be vented, resulting in the loss of valuable fuel. Eliminating such propellant losses is crucial to the success of NASA’s most ambitious missions, including future crewed journeys to Mars, which will require storing large amounts of cryogenic propellant in space for months or even years. So far, cryogenic fuels have only been used for missions lasting less than a week.

“To go to Mars and have a sustainable presence, you need to preserve cryogens for use as rocket or lander return propellant,” Henkel said. “Rockets currently control their propellant through margin, where larger tanks are designed to hold more propellant than what is needed for a mission. Propellant loss isn’t an issue with short trips because the loss is factored into this margin. But, human exploration missions to Mars or longer stays at the Moon will require a different approach because of the very large tanks that would be needed.”

The Cryogenic Fluid Management Portfolio Project is a cross-agency team based at NASA Marshall and the agency’s Glenn Research Center in Cleveland. The cryogenic portfolio’s work is under NASA’s Technology Demonstration Missions Program, part of NASA’s Space Technology Mission Directorate, and is comprised of more than 20 individual technology development activities.

Learn more about cryogenic fluid management:

https://go.nasa.gov/cfm
articles.reasoning: The article describes a significant technological advancement by NASA in cryogenic fluid management, which is crucial for long-duration space missions to the Moon and Mars. This breakthrough addresses a major challenge in space exploration—preserving super cold propellants without loss—thereby enabling sustainable human presence on other planets. It is positive and hopeful as it supports future space exploration and scientific progress.
articles.personality_title: NASA’s cool new trick keeps rocket fuel super cold in space
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Keeping rocket fuel super cold in space is a big challenge. Even though space is extremely cold, fuel can heat up because of the spacecraft’s own systems, sunlight, and engine exhaust. This makes storing liquid fuel for long missions to places like the Moon and Mars tricky.

**What happened**
NASA has developed a smart new way to manage ultra-cold fuel, called cryogenic fluid management. This technology carefully stores, moves, and measures super cold fluids so they don’t warm up and evaporate during long space trips.

**Impact**
This breakthrough means future missions can carry fuel safely for longer periods. It’s a key step toward living and working on the Moon and Mars, as it helps keep rockets and habitats powered without wasting precious fuel.

**What's next step**
NASA plans to continue testing this technology in space and improve it further. The goal is to support upcoming deep-space missions and make human exploration of other planets more practical and reliable.

**One-sentence takeaway**
NASA’s new fuel-cooling tech paves the way for longer, safer space journeys to the Moon, Mars, and beyond.
articles.personality_title_fr: La nouvelle astuce de la NASA pour garder le carburant super froid dans l’espace
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Conserver le carburant de fusée très froid dans l’espace est un grand défi. Même si l’espace est extrêmement froid, le carburant peut chauffer à cause des systèmes du vaisseau, de la lumière du soleil et des gaz d’échappement. Cela rend difficile le stockage du carburant liquide pour les longues missions vers la Lune et Mars.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
La NASA a mis au point une nouvelle méthode intelligente pour gérer le carburant ultra-froid, appelée gestion cryogénique des fluides. Cette technologie stocke, déplace et mesure soigneusement les fluides très froids pour éviter qu’ils ne se réchauffent et s’évaporent pendant les longs voyages spatiaux.

**Impact**
Cette avancée signifie que les futures missions pourront transporter du carburant en toute sécurité plus longtemps. C’est une étape clé pour vivre et travailler sur la Lune et Mars, car elle aide à alimenter les fusées et les habitats sans gaspiller de carburant précieux.

**Prochaine étape**
La NASA prévoit de continuer à tester cette technologie dans l’espace et de l’améliorer. L’objectif est de soutenir les futures missions lointaines et de rendre l’exploration humaine d’autres planètes plus pratique et fiable.

**Une phrase clé**
La nouvelle technologie de refroidissement de carburant de la NASA ouvre la voie à des voyages spatiaux plus longs et plus sûrs vers la Lune, Mars et au-delà.
articles.personality_title_es: El nuevo truco de la NASA para mantener el combustible súper frío en el espacio
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Mantener el combustible de cohete súper frío en el espacio es un gran desafío. Aunque el espacio es extremadamente frío, el combustible puede calentarse por los sistemas de la nave, la luz solar y los gases de escape. Esto hace que sea difícil almacenar el combustible líquido para misiones largas a la Luna y Marte.

**Qué pasó**
La NASA desarrolló una forma inteligente de manejar el combustible ultra frío, llamada gestión criogénica de fluidos. Esta tecnología almacena, mueve y mide cuidadosamente los fluidos súper fríos para evitar que se calienten y evaporen durante los viajes largos en el espacio.

**Impacto**
Este avance significa que las futuras misiones pueden llevar combustible de forma segura por más tiempo. Es un paso clave para vivir y trabajar en la Luna y Marte, ya que ayuda a mantener las naves y hábitats con energía sin desperdiciar combustible valioso.

**Próximo paso**
La NASA planea seguir probando esta tecnología en el espacio y mejorarla. El objetivo es apoyar misiones espaciales profundas y hacer la exploración humana de otros planetas más práctica y confiable.

**Frase para recordar**
La nueva tecnología para enfriar combustible de la NASA abre el camino para viajes espaciales más largos y seguros hacia la Luna, Marte y más allá.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a futuristic spacecraft’s sleek cryogenic fuel tank wrapped in layered insulation blankets with gentle, glowing blue and silver tubes coiling around it inside a softly lit vacuum chamber, symbolizing advanced two-stage cooling technology preserving super cold liquid hydrogen and oxygen for long space missions.

articles.title: Hubble Snaps Galaxy Cluster’s Portrait
articles.summary: A massive, spacetime-warping cluster of galaxies is the setting of today’s NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image. The galaxy cluster in question is Abell 209, located 2.8 billion light-years away in the constellation Cetus (the Whale). This Hubble image of Abell 209 shows more than a hundred galaxies, but there’s more to this cluster than even Hubble’s discerning […]
articles.content:
This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image features the galaxy cluster Abell 209. ESA/Hubble & NASA, M. Postman, P. Kelly

A massive, spacetime-warping cluster of galaxies is the setting of today’s NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image. The galaxy cluster in question is Abell 209, located 2.8 billion light-years away in the constellation Cetus (the Whale).

This Hubble image of Abell 209 shows more than a hundred galaxies, but there’s more to this cluster than even Hubble’s discerning eye can see. Abell 209’s galaxies are separated by millions of light-years, and the seemingly empty space between the galaxies is filled with hot, diffuse gas that is visible only at X-ray wavelengths. An even more elusive occupant of this galaxy cluster is dark matter: a form of matter that does not interact with light. Dark matter does not absorb, reflect, or emit light, effectively making it invisible to us. Astronomers detect dark matter by its gravitational influence on normal matter. Astronomers surmise that the universe is comprised of 5% normal matter, 25% dark matter, and 70% dark energy.

Hubble observations, like the ones used to create this image, can help astronomers answer fundamental questions about our universe, including mysteries surrounding dark matter and dark energy. These investigations leverage the immense mass of a galaxy cluster, which can bend the fabric of spacetime itself and create warped and magnified images of background galaxies and stars in a process called gravitational lensing.

While this image lacks the dramatic rings that gravitational lensing can sometimes create, Abell 209 still shows subtle signs of lensing at work, in the form of streaky, slightly curved galaxies within the cluster’s golden glow. By measuring the distortion of these galaxies, astronomers can map the distribution of mass within the cluster, illuminating the underlying cloud of dark matter. This information, which Hubble’s fine resolution and sensitive instruments help to provide, is critical for testing theories of how our universe evolved.

Text Credit: ESA/Hubble

Image credit: ESA/Hubble & NASA, M. Postman, P. Kelly
articles.reasoning: This news highlights a significant scientific observation by the Hubble Space Telescope that advances our understanding of the universe, dark matter, and dark energy. It is uplifting because it showcases human curiosity and technological achievement in exploring fundamental cosmic mysteries.
articles.personality_title: Hubble captures stunning image of distant galaxy cluster Abell 209
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
The Hubble Space Telescope, a powerful eye in space operated by NASA and ESA, recently focused on a giant group of galaxies called Abell 209. This cluster is incredibly far from us—about 2.8 billion light-years away in the constellation Cetus, also known as the Whale.

**What happened**
Hubble took a detailed picture showing over a hundred galaxies packed together in Abell 209. This cluster bends space and time around it, revealing clues about some of the universe’s biggest mysteries, like dark matter and dark energy, which we can’t see directly but know are there because of their effects.

**Impact**
By capturing this image, Hubble helps scientists learn more about how galaxies group and interact, and about the invisible forces shaping the cosmos. This discovery is a shining example of human curiosity and high-tech achievement working together to uncover the secrets of the universe.

**What's next step**
Scientists will continue studying images like this to better understand the role of dark matter and energy in galaxy clusters. Future space telescopes and research will build on Hubble’s work to dive deeper into these cosmic puzzles.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Hubble’s stunning snapshot of Abell 209 brings us closer to understanding the mysterious forces shaping our universe.
articles.personality_title_fr: Hubble capture une image impressionnante de l’amas de galaxies lointain Abell 209
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le télescope spatial Hubble, un puissant observatoire en orbite géré par la NASA et l’ESA, a récemment ciblé un immense groupe de galaxies appelé Abell 209. Cet amas est situé à environ 2,8 milliards d’années-lumière dans la constellation de la Baleine (Cetus).

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Hubble a pris une photo détaillée montrant plus d’une centaine de galaxies rassemblées dans Abell 209. Cet amas déforme l’espace-temps autour de lui, révélant des indices sur certains des plus grands mystères de l’univers, comme la matière noire et l’énergie noire, invisibles mais détectables par leurs effets.

**Impact**
En capturant cette image, Hubble aide les scientifiques à mieux comprendre comment les galaxies se regroupent et interagissent, ainsi que les forces invisibles qui façonnent le cosmos. Cette découverte est un bel exemple de la curiosité humaine et de la technologie de pointe unies pour percer les secrets de l’univers.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs vont continuer à étudier des images comme celle-ci pour mieux comprendre le rôle de la matière et de l’énergie noires dans les amas de galaxies. Les futurs télescopes spatiaux et recherches s’appuieront sur le travail de Hubble pour approfondir ces énigmes cosmiques.

**Une phrase à retenir**
Le magnifique cliché d’Abell 209 pris par Hubble nous rapproche un peu plus de la compréhension des forces mystérieuses qui façonnent notre univers.
articles.personality_title_es: Hubble captura una impresionante imagen del lejano cúmulo de galaxias Abell 209
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El telescopio espacial Hubble, un potente observatorio en el espacio operado por la NASA y la ESA, se enfocó recientemente en un enorme grupo de galaxias llamado Abell 209. Este cúmulo está a unos 2.8 mil millones de años luz de distancia en la constelación de Cetus, también conocida como la Ballena.

**Qué pasó**
Hubble tomó una imagen detallada que muestra más de cien galaxias reunidas en Abell 209. Este cúmulo curva el espacio y el tiempo a su alrededor, revelando pistas sobre algunos de los mayores misterios del universo, como la materia oscura y la energía oscura, que no podemos ver directamente pero sabemos que existen por sus efectos.

**Impacto**
Al capturar esta imagen, Hubble ayuda a los científicos a aprender más sobre cómo se agrupan e interactúan las galaxias, y sobre las fuerzas invisibles que moldean el cosmos. Este descubrimiento es un brillante ejemplo de la curiosidad humana y la alta tecnología trabajando juntas para descubrir los secretos del universo.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos continuarán estudiando imágenes como esta para entender mejor el papel de la materia oscura y la energía oscura en los cúmulos de galaxias. Los futuros telescopios espaciales y las investigaciones se basarán en el trabajo de Hubble para profundizar en estos enigmas cósmicos.

**Conclusión en una frase**
La impresionante imagen de Hubble de Abell 209 nos acerca a entender las misteriosas fuerzas que moldean nuestro universo.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a vast cosmic cluster glowing softly with dozens of golden-hued galaxies floating amid a gentle dark space, where subtle, curved streaks of light warp and bend around invisible shapes symbolizing dark matter’s presence, all rendered in natural, muted tones to evoke a serene and mysterious celestial portrait.
